Don't Stop the Music is the third studio album by Swedish pop singer Robyn . It was released on 30 October 2002 in Sweden by BMG . The album peaked at number two in her native Sweden, and the two singles " Keep This Fire Burning " and " Don't Stop the Music " were both top 10 hits. In 2003, Don't Stop the Music was certified platinum by IFPI , and has sold over 60,000 copies in Sweden. The song "Should Have Known" also appears on Robyn's self-titled fourth studio album from 2005 in a re-recorded version. Despite the album's two singles being released through most of Europe, the album was only available in Sweden and Japan  until 2019, when it received a worldwide digital release on Konichiwa Records. Track listing ^[a] signifies an additional producer ^[b] signifies a vocal producer Charts and certifications Release history References External links Don't Stop the Music at Discogs v t e

In", and "In The Country" ( Chicago II ), " Free " ( Chicago III ), " Dialogue (Part I & II) " ( Chicago V ), " Wishing You Were Here " ( Chicago VII ), and " Brand New Love Affair " ( Chicago VIII ). His vocal delivery was later described by Lamm as "The White Ray Charles ". Pankow, who wrote "Make Me Smile", tried rehearsing the song with various members singing lead, but ultimately settled on Kath, saying "bingo – 'that' was the voice." Kath was one of the three primary lead singers of Chicago, with a vocal range between those of the other two, Peter Cetera 's higher tenor and Robert Lamm 's fuller, lower baritone. He often collaborated with Cetera on lead vocals as they did in " Dialogue (Part I & II) ," "Ain't It Blue," "In The Country," and " Brand New Love Affair ". Kath also played lead guitar and sang lead vocals on the closing song "Tell Me" in the 1973 drama movie Electra Glide in Blue . The song was used in the final episode of the television series Miami Vice . Personal life and death Kath had a self-admitted history of drug abuse , including alcohol . Seraphine knew that Kath had a high tolerance for drugs and he later recalled Kath telling him: "I'm going to get things under control ... if I don't, this stuff is going to kill me." Chicago bandmates, including Seraphine, had noted that he was then also becoming increasingly unhappy. The night before he died, Kath visited bandmate Laudir de Oliveira . De Oliveira offered him tea and the two spent all night talking. Guercio has said that Kath was finishing writing a solo album before he died and Pankow has adamantly denied that Kath was suicidal. Kath enjoyed target shooting and by 1978 he was regularly carrying guns. On Monday, January 23, after a party at the home of roadie and band technician Don Johnson in Woodland Hills, Los Angeles, California , Kath began to play with his guns. He spun his unloaded .38 revolver on his finger, put it to his temple and pulled the trigger. Johnson warned Kath several times to be careful. Kath picked up a semi-automatic 9 mm pistol and, leaning back in a chair, said to Johnson: "Don't worry about it ... Look, the clip is not even in it." His last words were, "What do you think I'm gonna do? Blow my brains out?" To calm Johnson's concerns, Kath showed him the empty magazine. Kath then replaced the magazine in the gun, put the gun to his temple and pulled the trigger. Apparently unbeknownst to Kath, the gun had a round in the chamber . He died instantly from the gunshot, eight days shy of his 32nd birthday. Kath left behind his wife, Camelia

Even are an Australian indie rock three-piece fronted by singer-songwriter-guitarist, Ashley Naylor with Matthew Cotter on drums and Wally Kempton (also known as Wally Meanie) on bass guitar and backing vocals. They formed in March 1994 and played regularly around the live music scene and toured both nationally and internationally. They have released eight studio albums, Less Is More (1996), Come Again (1998), A Different High (2001), Free Kicks (2004), Even (2007), In Another Time (2011), Satin Returns (2018), and Reverse Light Years (2021). History 1994–1995: Formation and early EPs Future members of Even, Matthew Cotter on drums and Ashley Naylor on lead vocals and lead guitar, played music together at a high school in Melbourne. They formed an indie band, The Swarm, with Francis Leach on vocals and David Rowland on bass guitar. The Swarm issued three independent singles between November 1988 and April 1991 before disbanding. In March 1994 Cotter and Naylor were joined by Roderick "Wally" Kempton (also a member of The Meanies , as Wally Meanie) on bass guitar to form an indie guitar pop group, Even. Even played their first gig in March 1994 at the Empress of India Hotel in Fitzroy . Ten years later Naylor told Michael Dwyer of The Age that "It was very exciting, because we did a soundcheck and people were applauding us... We were bristling to play, absolutely bursting with energy. Flaming youth, Kiss would have called it." Even signed to an independent label, Rubber Records. In May 1995 Even issued a six-track extended play, In Stereo , distributed by Shock Records . It was produced by Andy Baldwin, Andy O'Beirne, Lindsay Gravina and Bruce Mowson. National youth radio station, Triple J , added the track, "24 Hour Cynic", to high rotation. In late 1996 they provided a live-in-the-studio version of "24 Hour Cynic" for a various artists' compilation, Triple J – Live . Even followed in November 1995 with a five-track EP, Ten to Forty-Six , which included the lead track, "Stupid Dream". 1996–2003: Less Is More , Come Again and A Different High Even released their debut studio album, Less Is More on 10 June 1996 via Rubber Records/Shock Records. It was co-produced by Even with Greg Wales ( Drop City ) and mixed by Wales with Nick Launay . Australian musicologist, Ian McFarlane , felt it was "brimming with exceptional tunes ('Karmic Flop', 'Stop and Go Man', 'Dear Morris', 'She Told Me So' and 'Eternal Teen'

City ) and mixed by Wales with Nick Launay . Australian musicologist, Ian McFarlane , felt it was "brimming with exceptional tunes ('Karmic Flop', 'Stop and Go Man', 'Dear Morris', 'She Told Me So' and 'Eternal Teen' to name but a handful), a timeless feel and pop hooks by the truckload." He declared that the group had released "one of the best Australian debut albums of 1996." Less Is More provided three singles, "Don't Wait" (June), "Stop and Go Man" (September) and "Peaches and Cream" (February 1997). After supporting international acts, The Presidents of the United States, The Posies, Ash and Everclear, in Australia; Even toured the United States and then Europe from March 1997. At the ARIA Music Awards of 1997 in September Less Is More was nominated for Best Independent Release . In November 1997 they issued a third EP, One Side Not , with four tracks. It was recorded at Seed Studios by Wales with Tim Johnston. The group issued their second studio album, Come Again , on 28 September 1998, which was produced by Tony Lash (The Dandy Warhols, Eric Matthews). McFarlane felt it "fulfilled the promise of the debut with its full quota of bright guitar melodies and top-flight songs." AllMusic 's James Damas described it as "one of the most overlooked and consistent rock & roll albums of the late '90s." Tim Rogers of fellow Australian group, You Am I, quipped that it was his "favourite Beatles album". It provided three singles, "No Surprises" (August 1998), "Black Umbrella" (November) and "Sunshine Comes" (September 1999). From early 1999 Naylor collaborated with alternative country artist, Sherry Rich , to form a folk pop duo, The Grapes. They issued a self-titled album in October which McFarlane observed was "full of rich sixties melodies, catchy guitar hooks, perfect harmonies, jangling guitars and country influences." Even's third studio album, A Different High , was issued on 14 May 2001, which peaked at No. 48 on the ARIA Albums Chart , and reached No. 10 on the ARIA Alternative Albums Chart. Guesting on the album were Renée Geyer on vocals, Graham Lee (ex- The Triffids ) on pedal steel guitar and Bruce Haymes (of Paul Kelly Band ) on organ, piano and Wurlitzer. Damas opined that for A Different High , "the scales begin to tip more heavily toward the more bloated side of '70s classic rock and away from modern pop." David Simons of OnStage Magazine noticed that it "finds Naylor sharpening the hooks, tightening the grooves, and multiplying

Radha (1932 - 28 September 2025) and Jayalakshmi (1932 - 2014), popularly known as Radha Jayalakshmi ( Tamil : ராதா ஜெயலட்சுமி ), were an Indian Carnatic music vocalist duo as well as playback singers in films in the 1940s and 1950s. They later became teachers and trained notable Carnatic music singers. Jayalakshmi was the playback singer of the duo, but was credited as Radha Jayalakshmi in the cine field. Radha was her cousin and singing partner on stage performances. They were early vocalists in the duo singing trend in Carnatic music which started in the 1950s and includes performers like Bombay Sisters and Soolamangalam Sisters . In recent times, the trend has been continued by popular Carnatic music singers like Priya Sisters , their disciples, Ranjani Gayatri , Bellur sisters, Mambalam Sisters, Akkarai sisters , and others. The duo was awarded the 1981 Sangeet Natak Akademi Award in Carnatic Music – Vocal, given by the Sangeet Natak Akademi , India's National Academy for Music, Dance and Drama Vidushi Jayalakshmi died in Chennai on 27 May 2014. Early life and training Radha and Jayalakshmi's singing style belongs to the G. N. Balasubramaniam school, and they received their training in classical vocal music from the noted vocalist and teacher himself. Career Jayalakshmi has rendered songs in her trained, cultured and 'ringing' sweet voice in Tamil, Malayalam, Telugu and Kannada movies from the late 1940s to the early 60s. She also has a few playback singing credits from the 1970s. In Deivam, Kunnakkudi Vaidyanathan had both Radha and Jayalakshmi render Thiruchendooril Por Purindhu , a devotional song set in Thiruthani. This is perhaps the only film song sung by Radha of the duo. But both have given stage performances throughout India. The singers had no longer been giving performances towards the time of Jayalakshmi's death, but instead had shifted their efforts to teaching Carnatic music and were regarded as great teachers. Shanmukhapriya and Haripriya, popularly known as the Priya Sisters , were their students. Music composers Jayalakshmi sang for Jayalakshmi's most memorable songs date from the 50s films. S. Balachander S. M. Subbaiah Naidu G. Aswathama M. S. Gnanamani Shankar–Jaikishan Parur S.

" Keep This Fire Burning " is a song by Swedish recording artist Robyn , released as the first single from her third album Don't Stop the Music . The single was released in Sweden on 16 September 2002, where it became her highest charting single since 1995's " Do You Really Want Me (Show Respect) ". The song was also released as a single in Australia under the name " By Your Side " due to the Australian bushfires which were happening at the time. In 2008, a re-recorded version of the song appeared on the special edition of Robyn's eponymous album . British soul singer Beverley Knight released a cover of the song in 2004. Track listings CD single "Keep This Fire Burning" (Radio Original) – 3:52 "Keep This Fire Burning" (Instrumental) – 3:52 CD maxi single and Australian CD single "Keep This Fire Burning" (Radio Original) – 3:52 "Keep This Fire Burning" (Cherno Jah Remix) – 4:12 "Keep This Fire Burning" ( Martin Landquist 2002 Remix) – 4:16 "Keep This Fire Burning" (Twin 12" Club Mix) – 7:24 "Keep This Fire Burning" ( Ingrosso & Father Remix) – 7:18 "Keep This Fire Burning" (DJ Benji Remix) – 5:51 Personnel Written by Robyn, Remee , Ulf Lindström, Johan Ekhé Produced, arranged, recorded, mixed and instruments performed by Ghost Charts Beverley Knight version British soul singer Beverley Knight recorded a cover version of "Keep This Fire Burning" and released it as the third and final single from her fourth studio album, Affirmation (2004), on 14 March 2005. The production of the song, handled by Ghost, used the exact same instrumental as Robyn's original version, with slight mixing differences and additional orchestration by the Stockholm Session Strings. Included on the CD single release were mixes from Stargate (which sampled a portion of Robyn's original vocals) and Full Phat (featuring a rap from Estelle ). "Keep This Fire Burning" became Knight's sixth top-20 solo single in the UK, reaching number 16. communities.summary:
**Title**: Icelandic Eurovision Duo Stjórnin

**Summary**: Stjórnin is an Icelandic pop duo formed by Grétar Örvarsson and Sigríður “Sigga” Beinteinsdóttir. They achieved Iceland’s best Eurovision result to that date by placing 4th in Zagreb 1990 with “Eitt lag enn.” The pair later re-formed as Heart 2 Heart for the 1992 contest, and Beinteinsdóttir returned solo in 1994, making her Iceland’s first three-time Eurovision participant. Between 1990 and 2018 the group released eight albums and numerous singles, becoming staples of the Icelandic music scene.

**Keywords**: Eurovision, Iceland, Stjórnin, Sigga, 1990s pop

**Title**: Doretta's Dream Single

**Summary**: "Doretta's Dream" is a 1987 single by Sarah Brightman that adapts Puccini’s aria "Chi il bel sogno di Doretta" from the opera *La Rondine*. Charles Hart provided new English lyrics for the track, which also served as the theme for the film *A Room with a View*. The single couples this adaptation with another Puccini aria, "O mio babbino caro."

**Keywords**: Sarah Brightman, Puccini, Doretta's Dream, La Rondine, A Room with a View

**Title**: Pomplamoose Indie Duo

**Summary**: Pomplamoose is the husband-and-wife indie-pop duo of Jack Conte and Nataly Dawn, formed in 2008 and famed for viral YouTube “VideoSongs” that show every sound being performed. They parlayed early online success—100k songs sold in 2009 and over 640 million views to date—into ad placements for Toyota and Hyundai, multiple studio albums, and two seasons of a self-titled webcast. After marrying in 2016, the pair scaled back output in 2021 when Dawn was diagnosed with basal-cell carcinoma, while continuing to release new music and supporting charitable causes such as a 2010 book drive that donated 11,000+ books to a California charter school.

**Keywords**: Pomplamoose, VideoSongs, YouTube virality, indie pop, charity

**Title:** Even Band Discography & Career

**Summary:**  
Australian indie-rock trio Even, led by Ashley Naylor, formed in 1994 and built a 27-year catalogue of eight guitar-pop albums lauded for Beatles-esque hooks and '60s–'70s melodicism. Their 1996 debut *Less Is More* earned an ARIA nomination and was later voted one of Australia's greatest albums, while 2021's *Reverse Light Years* became their highest-charting release at #18 ARIA. Between studio records they toured internationally, issued multiple EPs and singles, and collaborated with artists such as Sherry Rich and Ian McLagan.

**Keywords:**  
Even band, Australian indie rock, Less Is More, ARIA charts, power pop

**Title**: Violent Femmes' "Add It Up"

**Summary**: "Add It Up" is a 1983 track by Violent Femmes that captures adolescent sexual frustration through blunt, memorable lyrics. Written by Gordon Gano in his bedroom, the song became a cult favorite despite—or because of—its explicit language, prompting radio edits that replace swear words with guitar stabs. Its enduring popularity is evidenced by its inclusion in films like *Reality Bites* and *Rocket Science*, the video game *Tony Hawk's Underground 2*, and a 2016 cover by Shawn Mendes on *The 100*, which the band praised for proving the song's timeless appeal.

**Keywords**: Violent Femmes, Add It Up, 1983 debut, explicit lyrics, pop-culture covers

**Title**: Jang Hyun-seung Career Journey

**Summary**: Jang Hyun-seung, formerly of Beast, transitioned from a YG trainee cut from Big Bang to a multifaceted solo artist. After debuting with Beast in 2009, he formed the duo Trouble Maker with Hyuna, achieving chart-topping success. Post-Beast, he launched a solo career under Cube, explored city-pop as ABLE, and re-signed under Warner Korea as Jang Hyunseung, releasing "Orbit" in 2025. His path also includes musical-theatre roles, military service, and label changes.

**Keywords**: Beast, Trouble Maker, solo debut, ABLE, MPLIFY Records

**Title**: "Keep This Fire Burning" Releases

**Summary**:  
"Keep This Fire Burning" is a 2002 single by Swedish artist Robyn that became her biggest domestic hit since 1995 and was retitled "By Your Side" in Australia amid bushfire concerns. The track spawned multiple remixes and was re-recorded for the 2008 special edition of her self-titled album. British soul singer Beverley Knight released a cover in 2005 using the same instrumental, adding orchestration and guest vocals from Estelle on remixes, peaking at UK #16. A 2008 dance version by Outsiders featuring Amanda Wilson later reached UK #80 after remixes by Wawa and Freemasons.

**Keywords**: Robyn, Beverley Knight, remixes, singles, cover versions

**Title**: Robyn's "Don't Stop the Music" Album  

**Summary**:  
"Don't Stop the Music" is Swedish pop artist Robyn’s third studio album, released on 30 October 2002 by BMG. It reached number two on the Swedish charts, achieved platinum certification in 2003, and sold over 60,000 copies domestically. The singles "Keep This Fire Burning" and "Don’t Stop the Music" both became top-10 hits, while the track "Should Have Known" was later re-recorded for her 2005 self-titled album. Although the singles circulated across Europe, the full album was officially available only in Sweden and Japan until its worldwide digital release on Konichiwa Records in 2019.  

**Keywords**: Robyn, Don’t Stop the Music, Swedish pop, 2002 album, platinum certification

**Title**: Madonna’s “Crazy for You” Success  

**Summary**:  
“Crazy for You” became Madonna’s second U.S. number-one hit in 1985, displacing “We Are the World” and topping charts in Canada, Australia, and New Zealand while reaching number two in the U.K. The ballad’s global sales earned gold discs in the U.S. and U.K., with over 782,000 British copies sold by 2015. Critics later hailed it as her first major ballad and a staple 1980s slow-dance track, praising its raw vocal appeal and propulsive production despite Madonna not writing it.  

**Keywords**: Madonna, Crazy for You, 1985 charts, ballad, certifications

**Title**: Michael Jackson’s “Billie Jean” Legacy

**Summary**:  
“Billie Jean” is a landmark 1983 single whose minimalist funk-disco groove, driven by an instantly recognizable bassline and Jackson’s paranoid vocal delivery, became one of the most influential tracks in pop history. Beyond topping charts worldwide, the song’s sonic DNA—drum intro, synth-bass pulse, and sparse three-note motif—has been dissected and praised for its perfect blend of rhythm, melody, and engineering clarity. Its cultural footprint spans answer songs, countless cover versions (The Bates, Sound Bluntz, Ian Brown, Chris Cornell), persistent club rotation exceeding 250,000 weekly plays, and perennial rankings among the greatest songs of all time by Rolling Stone, BBC Radio 2, and British TV polls.

**Keywords**:  
Billie Jean, Michael Jackson, Thriller, bassline, cover versions

**Title**: Terry Kath: Chicago’s Guitar Virtuoso  

**Summary**:  
Terry Kath was the founding guitarist and a principal lead singer of Chicago, celebrated for blending rock, jazz, and blues into the band’s signature sound. Self-taught and influenced by artists from The Ventures to Hendrix, Kath wrote or sang on key early tracks such as “25 or 6 to 4,” “Make Me Smile,” and “Introduction,” while his experimental guitar work—like the feedback-laden “Free Form Guitar”—showcased his technical daring. Revered by peers (Jimi Hendrix called him “the best guitarist in the universe”), Kath also shaped Chicago’s vocal palette with a Ray Charles–tinged baritone. Struggling with substance abuse and depression, he died at 31 from an accidental self-inflicted gunshot, prompting the band to memorialize him with songs like “Alive Again.”  

**Keywords**: Chicago guitarist, Terry Kath vocals, rock-jazz fusion, accidental death, underrated guitar legend

**Title**: ARCO Corporate History & Operations

**Summary**:  
ARCO, originally the Atlantic Richfield Company, was formed in 1966 through the merger of Atlantic Refining and Richfield Oil, becoming a major U.S. oil firm with global operations. It pioneered 4D seismic research, launched the ampm convenience-store chain, and briefly entered solar energy and mining via Anaconda Copper, which later saddled it with Superfund liabilities. After BP acquired ARCO in 2000, the brand survived on the West Coast, while Marathon now owns most U.S. ARCO stations.

**Keywords**: ARCO, Atlantic Richfield, BP acquisition, Anaconda Copper, Superfund site

**Title**: Unwritten Law Band History  

**Summary**:  
Unwritten Law is a melodic hardcore/pop-punk band formed in 1990, anchored by founding front-man Scott Russo and drummer Wade Youman. The group has weathered frequent lineup changes—especially in bass and guitar roles—while releasing seven studio albums, most recently *The Hum* (2022) after an 11-year gap. Their discography spans *Blue Room* (1994) through *Swan* (2011), with side projects like the 2016 acoustic compilation. Live controversies, such as the 2014 Perth power-cut incident and multiple departures/returns of Youman, punctuate a career marked by angsty lyrics and summer-themed punk-revival anthems.  

**Keywords**:  
Unwritten Law, melodic hardcore, pop-punk, lineup changes, The Hum

**Title**: Priya Sisters Carnatic Journey

**Summary**: Shanmukhapriya and Haripriya, known as the Priya Sisters, are a prominent Carnatic vocal duo trained from childhood by their father, Sri V.V. Subbaram, who relocated the family to Chennai to advance their music. They refined their craft under the guidance of Radha and Jayalakshmi, absorbing the legendary G. N. Balasubramaniam’s stylistic legacy, and later with Professor T. R. Subramaniam, expanding their repertoire of pallavis and kritis. Embodying the duo-singing tradition that began in the 1950s, they emphasize crystal-clear rendition so listeners can notate every kriti, sustaining a continuous learning ethos throughout their career.

**Keywords**: Priya Sisters, Carnatic duo, Radha-Jayalakshmi lineage, Chennai gurus, kriti clarity

**Title**: Greg Puciato's Vocal Artistry

**Summary**: Greg Puciato is celebrated for an exceptionally versatile voice that fuses crooning, screaming, falsetto and death growls, earning praise for clarity, variation and emotional impact rather than typical metal conventions. Self-taught and hyperlexic from childhood, he absorbed influences spanning Mike Patton, H.R., Maxwell, Seal, My Bloody Valentine and Stanley Kubrick, integrating filmic cadences and R&B phrasing into heavy music. Beyond technique, he prioritizes emotional honesty, capturing song mood first and refining details later, whether writing for the chaotic Dillinger Escape Plan or the synth-driven Black Queen. Despite relentless touring and self-management, he avoided lasting vocal damage and continues to expand his palette through guitar, programming and soundtrack work.

**Keywords**: vocal versatility, emotional honesty, genre-blending, self-taught, influences

**Title**: Radha-Jayalakshmi Carnatic Duo

**Summary**: Radha-Jayalakshmi were a pioneering Indian Carnatic vocal duo and 1940s-50s playback singers who popularized twin-voice classical performances. Trained by G. N. Balasubramaniam, Jayalakshmi sang in Tamil, Telugu, Malayalam and Kannada films while Radha joined her only on stage, setting a template later followed by Bombay Sisters, Priya Sisters and Ranjani-Gayatri. After retiring from concerts they became revered gurus, mentoring the Priya Sisters and earning the 1981 Sangeet Natak Akademi Award.

**Keywords**: Carnatic duo, playback singer, GNB school, Priya Sisters, Sangeet Natak Akademi

**Title**: Violent Femmes Band History  

**Summary**:  
Violent Femmes, the Milwaukee folk-punk trio formed in 1981, rose to cult fame with their platinum 1983 debut and became a touchstone for alternative, indie, and grunge scenes. After early success, the band cycled through breakups, lineup changes (notably drummers Victor DeLorenzo, Guy Hoffman, Brian Viglione), and stylistic shifts before disbanding in 2009 amid a lawsuit over song-licensing rights. They reunited in 2013, releasing new albums *We Can Do Anything* (2016) and *Hotel Last Resort* (2019) and continuing to tour with core members Gordon Gano and Brian Ritchie.  

**Keywords**:  
folk-punk, alternative rock, Milwaukee, lineup changes, reunion

**Title**: Highlight/Beast Group History  

**Summary**:  
The text traces the career of the South Korean boy group originally named Beast, formed under Cube Entertainment, and later rebranded as Highlight after moving to their own label, Around Us Entertainment. It covers their rise from 2009 debut reality shows through multi-platinum Korean and Japanese albums, military enlistments that temporarily reduced them to a four-member unit, and their 2021–2024 comebacks culminating in the 2025 single “Endless Ending” promoted under the reclaimed name Beast. Key milestones include chart-toppers like “Fiction,” the creation of their Around Us label, sold-out concerts after COVID-19 delays, and regaining trademark rights to their original name while continuing activities as Highlight.  

**Keywords**:  
Beast/Highlight, K-pop discography, military service, Around Us Entertainment, trademark reinstatement
